Award.AwardTitle: U.S. Egypt Cooperative Research: Surface Modification and Size Dependence of Magnetic Nanoparticles for Biomedical Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is to investigate effects of size, shape and surface modification of magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs), which have been used in biomedical applications such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), tissue engineering, hyperthermia, and gene and drug delivery. The US PI will be collaborating with Dr. Emad Girgis at the National Research Centre (NRC) in Egypt.

Intellectual Merit: In this project, the PIs will synthesize MNPs of different sizes and shapes and surface modification for in-vivo applications. The particle diameter and structure will be investigated using FESEM, TEM, and XRD analyses. The magnetic properties of the MNPs will be measured at room temperature using vibrating samples magnetometer. MNPs with a mean size of 5-10 nm will be prepared under inert atmosphere, with support of natural polymeric starch, by using chemical colloidal method. The surface of MNPs will be treated with a coordinatable agent for higher dispersion ability in water and retaining the superparamagnetic property. The prepared magnetic nanoparticles will be coated with starch, dextran, PEG, MPEG or polymerizable liposomes to extend their application potential in various fields of nano biomedicine. Before using the magnetic nanoparticles in biomedicine applications, we will investigate the genotoxicity of the MNPs to optimize the surface modification processes. Finding non- or minimal genotoxic MNPs is the final goal of this project. The results from this project will not only transform our understanding on the relationship between the genotoxicity and the surface modification on MNPs, but also provide pivotal guidelines in designing a new class of nanoparticles and coating materials for numerous biotechnology and biomedical applications.

Broader Impact: A postdoctoral student will be actively engaged in project and will have an opportunity to travel to Egypt during the project for an international research experience. The PI intends to collaborate with industrial researchers and to publish research results will be published on his website (http://wilhelmy.lci.kent.edu) for broad access. The proposed research will be integrated in educational and outreach programs. At the graduate level, the US PI will accommodate the research methods and results in a new course offering at KSU. In this course, graduate students will gain a broad exposure to soft matter and biomaterials and will have ample opportunities to gain teaching experience in lab demonstrations. Outcomes resulting from this collaborative effort between the Egyptian and US teams may be useful for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), gene and drug delivery applications.

The project is funded under the US-Egypt Joint Fund Program, which provides grants to scientists and engineers in both countries to undertake cooperative research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to investigate the surface modification of the magnetic nanoparticles prepared by colloidal method with different sizes and shapes. Various types of coating (starch, dextran, PEG, MPEG and SiO) and core materials (Fe3O4, ZnFe3O4, Co-B, and Co-Ni-B) have been tested in optical and magnetic properties and biocompatibility. The genotoxicity was investigated to optimize the used surface modification process. The in-vivo biocompatibility tests of the surface modified MNPs on mice were carried out using DNA fragmentation analysis, micronucleus tests and sperm morphology.

Our study has shown that nanoparticles such as cobalt- nickel and iron oxide could induce genotoxic effect at the high dose. It was inferred that coating and surface properties influence nanoparticles genotoxicity. Nanomaterials interact directly with tissues and cells after entering the body. Therefore, the basic criteria for its clinical application are safety and good biocompatibility, which is also important to the industrialization of nanomedicine. At present, evaluation of the biocompatibility of biomaterials is mainly carried out using in vivo tests. The current study indicates that pure Co-Ni-B revealed more toxicity than Fe3O4. Additionally, coated Co-Ni-B and Fe3O4 with PEG or SiO expressed far less toxicity than bare particles and those coated with starch.

This research reports that one of the coating processes produces non-photobleaching photoluminescent magnetic nanoparticles that are non-toxic and biocompatible without any addition of fluorophores. In addition, photoluminescent polymers can be produces by a simple process. These photoluminescent polymers are practically non-photobleachable. Their photoluminescent intensity and emission wavelength are found to be tunable by varying the processing conditions. They also respond to environmental pH. All the in vivo biocompatibility assessments show low toxicities of nanoparticles coated with the photoluminescent polymers. Since they are low-cost, bio-safe, non-photobleaching alternatives of conventional fluorophores, their future applications may cover a wide range from personal care products to industrial applications, including bio-safe fluorescent labels, dye-lasers, and dye-sensitized solar cells.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2012
Modified by: Chanjoong Kim
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project aims to investigate the surface modification of the magnetic nanoparticles prepared by colloidal method with different sizes and shapes. Various types of coating (starch, dextran, PEG, MPEG and SiO) and core materials (Fe3O4, ZnFe3O4, Co-B, and Co-Ni-B) have been tested in optical and magnetic properties and biocompatibility. The genotoxicity was investigated to optimize the used surface modification process. The in-vivo biocompatibility tests of the surface modified MNPs on mice were carried out using DNA fragmentation analysis, micronucleus tests and sperm morphology. Our study has shown that nanoparticles such as cobalt- nickel and iron oxide could induce genotoxic effect at the high dose. It was inferred that coating and surface properties influence nanoparticles genotoxicity. Nanomaterials interact directly with tissues and cells after entering the body. Therefore, the basic criteria for its clinical application are safety and good biocompatibility, which is also important to the industrialization of nanomedicine. At present, evaluation of the biocompatibility of biomaterials is mainly carried out using in vivo tests. The current study indicates that pure Co-Ni-B revealed more toxicity than Fe3O4. Additionally, coated Co-Ni-B and Fe3O4 with PEG or SiO expressed far less toxicity than bare particles and those coated with starch. This research reports that one of the coating processes produces non-photobleaching photoluminescent magnetic nanoparticles that are non-toxic and biocompatible without any addition of fluorophores. In addition, photoluminescent polymers can be produces by a simple process. These photoluminescent polymers are practically non-photobleachable. Their photoluminescent intensity and emission wavelength are found to be tunable by varying the processing conditions. They also respond to environmental pH. All the in vivo biocompatibility assessments show low toxicities of nanoparticles coated with the photoluminescent polymers. Since they are low-cost, bio-safe, non-photobleaching alternatives of conventional fluorophores, their future applications may cover a wide range from personal care products to industrial applications, including bio-safe fluorescent labels, dye-lasers, and dye-sensitized solar cells.
